nodes.description: 1982年夏天，美国应黎巴嫩政府请求派驻维和部队
nodes.support_text: Beirut Memorial In the summer of 1982, at the request of the Lebanese government, the United States agreed to establish a U.S. Military presence in that country to serve as a peacekeeping force in the conflict between warring Muslim and Christian factions.

nodes.description: 1983年3月24日，第24海军陆战队两栖单位进驻贝鲁特
nodes.support_text: On March 24, 1983, the 24th Marine Amphibious Unit, stationed at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, received orders to Beirut, Lebanon in support of that commitment.

nodes.description: 1983年10月23日，美军总部遭卡车炸弹袭击致241人遇难
nodes.support_text: In the early morning of October 23, 1983, the First Battalion, 8th Marines Headquarters building was destroyed by a non-Lebanese, terrorist-driven truck, laden with compressed gas-enhanced explosives.

nodes.description: 1983年10月当天，杰克逊维尔委员会启动纪念树种植计划
nodes.support_text: On the afternoon of this tragic bombing, the Commission met and decided to seek permission to plant memorial trees on Lejeune Boulevard, the main traffic artery joining Jacksonville and Camp Lejeune, to honor our fallen neighbors.

nodes.description: 1984年3月24日，纪念树项目正式落成
nodes.support_text: The completed tree project was dedicated on March 24, 1984.

nodes.description: 1986年5月，纪念广场建设启动并获4.5英亩土地
nodes.support_text: Camp Lejeune offered the Commission 4.5 acres of highly visible and publicly accessible land at the corner of Lejeune Boulevard and Montford Landing Road. This gift expanded the Commission's vision of the final form of the Memorial and serious fund raising was launched.

nodes.description: 1986年10月23日，纪念广场完成并举行 dedication 仪式
nodes.support_text: The completed Memorial was dedicated on October 23, 1986 with approximately 2000 people in attendance.

nodes.description: 1988年10月22日，青铜雕塑正式揭幕
nodes.support_text: The statue was dedicated on October 22, 1988, some five years after that tragic day in Beirut, Lebanon.

nodes.description: 1991年添加《The Other Wall》诗碑和 Grenada阵亡者姓名
nodes.support_text: In 1991, the Beirut families added the poem, The Other Wall, written by Robert A. Gannon of Derry, New Hampshire. The poem was cast in bronze and dedicated at a 1991 observance ceremony.

nodes.description: 持续开展年度纪念活动强化军民融合
nodes.support_text: Annually, an observance is held that includes the families of the deceased, military personnel and the civilian community, further cementing that relationship.

nodes.description: 1983年10月23日卡车炸弹袭击导致美军总部241人遇难后，社区因失去优秀男士震惊
nodes.support_text: 社区因失去这些优秀男士而震惊

nodes.support_text: On the afternoon of this tragic bombing, the Commission met and decided to seek permission to plant memorial trees on Lejeune Boulevard, the main traffic artery joining Jacksonville and Camp Lejeune, to honor our fallen neighbors.

nodes.description: 1986年5月纪念广场建设启动后，在4.5英亩土地上铭刻'他们以和平到来'的青铜铭文
nodes.support_text: 纪念墙上的文字'THEY CAME IN PEACE'被刻上青铜材质

nodes.description: 格林纳达冲突中三名海军飞行员牺牲事件
nodes.support_text: 社区的三名海军飞行员在格林纳达被杀害
